field_edited_text.value:
Key Bridge from Fort Armistead’s shoreline





Development History

Hawkins Point was originally part of an
estate called “Cromwell’s Inheritance.” At
the site of what is now Fort Armistead, a
quarantine station built in 1779 housed
victims of the yellow fever epidemic. The
facility remained in use until 1830. Another
quarantine station was built nearby at
Leading Point in 1881 for smallpox victims
and was used as a health station until 1961.
Today this 18 acre property is owned by
the Maryland Port Administration and used
for a dredge spoil disposal facility.

The area’s first industry was Chappel’s
sulfuric acid plant, opened in 1883. The
plant was bought by the Davison Chemical
Co. in 1903 which has since become a
world leading manufacturer of superphos-
phates. The construction of a wooden
drawbridge across Curtis Creek in 1898
provided the stimulus for development in
the area and industrial activity spread from
the Fairfield peninsula to Hawkins Point.

The 46 acre Fort Armistead, originally
built in 1898 to protect the harbor during
the Spanish American war, was acquired by







the City in 1927, nine years after Hawkins
Point was annexed by Baltimore. During
World War 11, this shorefront park was
retained as an ammunition storage depot.

After the war industrial development
resulted in some site improvements to the
area. In 1979 the Francis Scott Key Bridge, a
four lane, 4/5-mile long, arched span, was
built across the harbor from Hawkins Point
to Sollers Point in Baltimore County. Much
of the interior of Hawkins Point, however,
still remains in a semi-rural state.

Refurbished Fort Armistead Park
